# About Akili Interactive

Akili Interactive, founded on January 1, 2011, is a digital therapeutics company that integrates neuroscience with technology and video game entertainment to develop treatments for cognitive disorders. The company is particularly known for its innovative approach to treating attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) through video game-based therapies. Akili's flagship product, EndeavorRx, is a prescription digital therapeutic designed to improve attention function in children aged 8-12 with ADHD. The company also offers EndeavorOTC, a treatment option for adults with ADHD, expanding its reach to a broader audience [(Crunchbase, 2025)](https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/akili).

Akili primarily operates in the B2C market, serving children with ADHD and their families, as well as adults with ADHD. Their products are distributed through licensed healthcare providers. The company has received significant attention since gaining FDA clearance for EndeavorRx in 2020 and went public in 2022 with a valuation of approximately $1 billion [(Aguilar, STAT News, 2024)](https://www.statnews.com/2024/05/29/virtual-therapeutics-acquire-akili-video-games-adhd/).

The company has undergone significant changes, including a recent merger with Virtual Therapeutics, which is expected to enhance its capabilities in creating immersive digital health solutions. This strategic move follows Akili's decision to wind down its existing commercial operations and focus on licensing agreements, particularly with Japanese pharmaceutical company Shionogi [(Tracy, PharmExec, 2024)](https://www.pharmexec.com/view/virtual-therapeutics-akili-interactive-strike-definitive-merger-agreement-seeking-to-improve-mental-health-through-immersive-video-games).

Akili has raised a total of $270 million in funding, with notable investments including $110 million and $50 million rounds in May 2021 [(Crunchbase, 2025)](https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/akili). The company is supported by investment firms such as Baillie Gifford, CLSA, and Polaris Partners.

# Key Personnel

Matt Franklin serves as the CEO of Akili Interactive. He has emphasized the strategic importance of the merger with Virtual Therapeutics, highlighting the potential to expand the company's reach in the digital health sector. Franklin's leadership reflects a commitment to addressing the growing mental health crisis through innovative digital solutions [(Tracy, PharmExec, 2024)](https://www.pharmexec.com/view/virtual-therapeutics-akili-interactive-strike-definitive-merger-agreement-seeking-to-improve-mental-health-through-immersive-video-games).

# News

## Merger with Virtual Therapeutics

In 2024, Akili Interactive announced a merger with Virtual Therapeutics, a move expected to enhance its capabilities in digital health solutions. The merger will allow Akili to operate as a wholly owned subsidiary of Virtual Therapeutics, with shareholders receiving $34 million in cash [(Tracy, PharmExec, 2024)](https://www.pharmexec.com/view/virtual-therapeutics-akili-interactive-strike-definitive-merger-agreement-seeking-to-improve-mental-health-through-immersive-video-games). This decision follows Akili's strategy to focus on licensing agreements and partnerships, particularly with Shionogi [(Aguilar, STAT News, 2024)](https://www.statnews.com/2024/05/29/virtual-therapeutics-acquire-akili-video-games-adhd/).

## Financial and Operational Changes

Akili Interactive has faced financial challenges, leading to layoffs and a strategic shift in operations. In April 2024, the company announced plans to lay off 46% of its staff and explore strategic options amid sluggish sales [(Mario Aguilar, 2024-04-30)](https://www.statnews.com/2024/04/30/akili-interactive-digital-therapeutics-firm-announce-layoffs-restructuring/). The merger with Virtual Therapeutics is part of Akili's efforts to stabilize and grow its business in the competitive digital therapeutics market.

## Market Position and Future Prospects

The digital therapeutics market is projected to grow significantly, with a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of around 20-25% from 2023 to 2030 [(Ratakonda, Artixio, 2024)](https://www.artixio.com/post/digital-therapeutics-combining-technology-for-better-health-outcomes). Akili's focus on cognitive disorders positions it well within this expanding market, especially as the demand for innovative ADHD treatments rises. The merger with Virtual Therapeutics is expected to enhance Akili's product offerings and market reach, potentially leading to new developments in digital health solutions for mental health [(Tracy, PharmExec, 2024)](https://www.pharmexec.com/view/virtual-therapeutics-akili-interactive-strike-definitive-merger-agreement-seeking-to-improve-mental-health-through-immersive-video-games).

# Conclusion

Akili Interactive is at a pivotal moment in its evolution, transitioning through a merger that aims to strengthen its position in the digital therapeutics market. With a proven product in EndeavorRx and expanding applications for ADHD treatment across various age groups, Akili is well-positioned to capitalize on the growing demand for digital health solutions. The company's strategic focus on partnerships and licensing agreements will be crucial as it navigates the complexities of the healthcare landscape and seeks to deliver value to its stakeholders.

# Akili Interactive Summary

## Company Overview
Akili Interactive is a pioneering company that merges neuroscience with technology and video game entertainment to create digital medicines. Their mission is to transform the treatment of cognitive impairments, particularly through engaging video game experiences rather than traditional pharmaceuticals. Their flagship product, **EndeavorRx**, is designed to improve attention function in children aged 8-12 with ADHD.

## Company History
Founded with the vision of challenging the conventional methods of medicine, Akili has positioned itself at the forefront of digital therapeutics, focusing on innovative solutions for cognitive health.

## Products and Services
- **EndeavorRx**: A digital therapeutic aimed at improving attention in children with ADHD. It is not a standalone treatment and should be used as part of a comprehensive therapeutic program. 
- **EndeavorOTC**: A new treatment option for adults with ADHD, expanding the company's offerings to a broader audience.

## Customers
Akili primarily serves children with ADHD and their families, as well as adults with ADHD. Their products are available through licensed healthcare providers.

## Leadership Team
The leadership team at Akili is committed to innovation and accountability, fostering a culture that encourages creativity, inclusivity, and well-being among employees and patients alike.

## Company Culture
Akili promotes a culture defined by the following values:

- **Be Bold**: Embrace risks and challenge the status quo.
- **Be Creative**: Encourage innovative thinking and solutions.
- **Be Inclusive**: Value diverse perspectives and respect all voices.
- **Be Accountable**: Take responsibility for actions and commitments.
- **Be Well**: Focus on the health and well-being of patients and employees.

## Research and Insights
Akili has conducted studies highlighting the challenges faced by employees with ADHD in the workplace, emphasizing the need for better support and understanding from employers. Their research indicates that employees with ADHD often feel limited by treatment options and face misconceptions that hinder their professional growth.

## Supporters
Akili has garnered support from various investment firms and partners, including Baillie Gifford, CLSA, and Polaris Partners, which have contributed to its growth and development in the digital health sector.

## Conclusion
Akili Interactive is at the forefront of digital medicine, leveraging technology to create engaging therapeutic experiences for individuals with cognitive impairments. Their commitment to innovation, inclusivity, and accountability positions them as a leader in the evolving landscape of healthcare.

For more information, visit [Akili Interactive](https://www.akiliinteractive.com/).

# [EndeavorRx — Akili Interactive](https://www.akiliinteractive.com/endeavorrx)
EndeavorRx Indications, Safety and Cautions

Indications:

EndeavorRx is a digital therapeutic indicated to improve attention function as measured by computer-based testing in children ages 8-12 years old with primarily inattentive or combined-type ADHD, who have a demonstrated attention issue. Patients who engage with EndeavorRx demonstrate improvements in a digitally assessed measure, Test of Variables of Attention (TOVA®), of sustained and selective attention and may not display benefits in typical behavioral symptoms, such as hyperactivity. EndeavorRx should be considered for use as part of a therapeutic program that may include clinician-directed therapy, medication, and/or educational programs, which further address symptoms of the disorder.

Safety:

Of 538 participants using EndeavorRx, 50 participants (9.3%) experienced treatment-related adverse events (probable, likely), and three participants experienced treatment-related adverse events with the digital control, in studies where a control was used. EndeavorRx associated adverse events included frustration (6.1%), headache (1.3%), dizziness (0.6%), emotional reaction (0.4%), nausea (0.4%), and aggression (0.2%). There were no serious adverse events. All adverse events were generally transient. Only 3 events led to device discontinuation, and no subject reported lasting or irreversible effects after discontinuation.

Cautions:

Rx only: Federal law restricts this device to sale by or on the order of a physician. EndeavorRx should only be used by the patient for whom the prescription was written. For medical questions, please contact your child’s healthcare provider. If you are experiencing a medical emergency, please dial 911. EndeavorRx is not intended to be used as a stand-alone therapeutic and is not a substitution for your child’s medication.

If your child experiences frustration, emotional reaction, dizziness, nausea, headache, eye-strain, or joint pain while playing EndeavorRx pause the treatment. If the problem persists contact your child’s healthcare provider. If your child experiences a seizure stop the treatment and contact your child’s healthcare provider.

EndeavorRx may not be appropriate for patients with photo-sensitive epilepsy, color blindness, or physical limitations that restrict use of a mobile device; parents should consult with their child’s healthcare provider.

Please follow all of your mobile device manufacturer’s instructions for the safe operation of your mobile device. For example, this may include appropriate volume settings, proper battery charging, not operating the device if damaged, and proper device disposal. Contact your mobile device manufacturer for any questions or concerns that pertain to your device.

# [Products — Akili Interactive](https://www.akiliinteractive.com/products)
Of 538 participants using EndeavorRx in clinical studies, 50 participants (9.3%) experienced treatment-related adverse events including frustration, headache, dizziness, emotional reaction, nausea, and aggression. There were no serious adverse events reported.

EndeavorRx is only available through a licensed health care provider. It is not intended to be used as a stand-alone therapeutic and is not a substitution for a child’s medication. EndeavorRx may not be appropriate for patients with photo-sensitive epilepsy, color blindness, or physical limitations that restrict use of a mobile device; parents should consult with their child’s health care provider.

Families should contact their child’s health care provider and review the important indications, safety and caution information in the Instructions for Use before using the EndeavorRx treatment.

# [ADHD in The Workplace — Akili Interactive](https://www.akiliinteractive.com/workplacesurvey)
Employees with ADHD are navigating their careers with intention, but a lack of adequate support. To cultivate an inclusive and thriving work environment, companies must transcend conventional approaches and provide better guidance for managers, and more comprehensive support for employees. These insights emerge from the new ADHD in the Workplace Study conducted by Akili and Wakefield Research, shedding light on the need and opportunity for ADHD accommodations at work to maximize the potential of a neurodiverse workforce.

Information was collected from US employed adults¹: 500 US employed adults with ADHD and 500 US managers (with or without ADHD), to understand the everyday challenges and experiences of those with ADHD at work. The survey covered the impact of impairment, disclosure to employers, experiences of stigma, manager misconceptions, treatment options, and more.

The research revealed that employees with ADHD face compounding challenges at work that can sidetrack career goals and take a toll on mental health.

87% of employees with ADHD report experiencing a negative impact of ADHD on their career

97% feel they would be capable of accomplishing more if they could better manage their symptoms.

95% feel limited by the number of treatment options available to them.

Employees with ADHD are seeking a more nuanced understanding and awareness from their supervisors of their strengths and needs for additional support, but managers feel unequipped to fully provide that support. Namely, 81% of managers report that they don’t feel completely prepared to appropriately address employee needs if an employee discloses an ADHD diagnosis.

If companies don’t take action to support their employees with ADHD, they run the risk of driving these employees away, with additional impacts on engagement and productivity. In light of the ongoing stimulant medication shortage (see FDA-DEA letter 2023), it has become even more urgent to support employees with adequate and varied resources. The report explores how companies should enhance their training for managers on workplace resources and benefits, as well as provide more treatment options for employees with ADHD. Akili has expanded options available with the launch of EndeavorOTC.

The Impact of Misconceptions about ADHD in the Workplace

In today’s workplace, misconceptions about ADHD abound.

92% of employees believe that their colleagues hold misconceptions about ADHD, the most common of which is “people with ADHD just need to try harder”

75% of employees with ADHD report experiencing increased micromanagement by supervisors relative to their peers

56% believe their condition has specifically led them to being demoted, overlooked for promotions, or their job responsibilities being taken away

This figure jumps to 65% for parents with ADHD, highlighting the varied challenges of those with multiple home and work responsibilities

Beyond Misconceptions: The Daily Realities of ADHD in the Workplace

While misconceptions about ADHD serve to hinder employees with ADHD, the genuine challenges posed by ADHD symptoms also impact daily work experiences.

Nearly 2 in 3 (65%) of employees with ADHD say that accomplishing day-to-day work tasks while managing ADHD symptoms poses a moderate to significant challenge

54% say they’re getting by, but would need more support to reach their full potential

19% say they are barely getting by and really need additional support.

The most prevalent symptoms include being easily distracted or sidetracked, with 59% of employees with ADHD citing this as a primary concern, followed by 56% who report a lack of focus and engagement at work. These struggles are not limited to challenges with focusing attention, as 32% of employees report difficulty building relationships with colleagues. Gender nuances emerge in this context as well. Overall women reported more symptoms on average than men (4.6 symptoms vs. 4.0 symptoms).

ADHD takes a toll on employees in multiple ways, and 88% of employees with ADHD report that the stimulant shortage has further impacted their work. The vast majority of employees with ADHD (90%) describe errors, conflicts, or extra hours at work as a result of challenges managing their ADHD. Nearly half (46%) have missed a deadline or meeting. In addition, employees have duplicated work that had already been done (31%), sent incorrect information to a boss or client (31%) or missed work altogether (31%) as a result of challenges managing their ADHD.

This is consistent with previous research finding that employees with ADHD may lose an average of 29 days of productivity per year in the US as compared to their colleagues without ADHD.

Furthermore, unmanaged ADHD symptoms can also be a reinforcing cycle, as 44% of employees with ADHD report that challenges managing their symptoms have caused them to feel unmotivated. Additionally 71% have reported it has led to them feeling anxious and 40% have reported it has led to them feeling depressed, further adding to the burden of the disorder.

On the other hand, nearly all employees with ADHD (98%) recognize that there are positive aspects of their ADHD that have helped them at work including increased creativity (51%), ability to think outside the box (49%), and higher levels of empathy (46%). Tapping into these strengths can be a powerful way to enhance workplace satisfaction, engagement and outcomes.

For managers, there appears to be a high level of familiarity with ADHD in general, with 83% of managers reporting that they are very or extremely familiar with ADHD. Of the managers surveyed, 21% report personally having ADHD. While this could be due to selection bias, it may also be that there are high levels of people with ADHD in management positions relative to the overall prevalence. Additionally, 74% of managers know someone at a current or previous job with ADHD and 37% directly supervised someone that they believed or confirmed had an ADHD diagnosis. While these numbers are encouraging, awareness is not the same as understanding how best to help.

In fact, 59% of managers report that they don’t feel completely prepared to appropriately respond if an employee tells them that they have ADHD. This gap between awareness and preparation underscores the need for more comprehensive training and education for managers.

The Value of Support

For employees diagnosed with ADHD, understanding and support from their employers and direct supervisors often take precedence over other workplace factors. 93% of employees with ADHD rate having a supervisor who knows how to support and work with them as more valuable than any office perk. When telling a supervisor about their ADHD, employees are looking for both practical support from supervisors on their working styles as well as additional workplace resources. For example, 55% of employees hope to gain acceptance of how their work style may differ from that of their colleagues and 24% are hoping for workplace resources.

The lack of training and resources has a direct impact on companies’ abilities to retain talent. For nearly half of employees with ADHD (45%), the challenges they experience in managing their symptoms at their current job have caused them to search for a new one or to consider doing so with nearly 1 in 10 (9%) already looking for a new position. This is especially true for younger generations – 62% of Gen Z and 57% of Millennials reported looking for, or planning to look for, a new job specifically because of challenges related to their ADHD (compared to 45% of Gen X and 26% of Boomers).

Recommendations

Employees | For employees, there is a clearly expressed need for both acceptance of one’s own unique working style and additional tools and resources. Acceptance can start with a recognition of one’s own strengths and thinking about ways to shape your work tasks to fit your own learning style. This could involve identifying tasks that are energizing and that you are able to focus on and brainstorm ways to incorporate more of them into your day or intersperse them between more boring tasks. It may also involve tasks that involve higher stress, pressure or mental challenge (this can be a superpower!), novel or varied tasks, hands-on work, and/or topics of personal interest. As a next step, it can be helpful to develop a system of organization that complements your cognitive style, and to build your attentional control by engaging in specific cognitive activities designed to target and strengthen mental processes needed for attention.

The next set of strategies is based on communicating a need for support from others. When talking with a coworker or supervisor about having ADHD, think about your goal in telling them. Is it so others will better understand? For support? Figuring out how to better work together? Knowing the purpose will help guide the conversation. Based on your goal, share relevant information, whether it’s basic info or misconceptions about ADHD or more personally relevant experiences and strengths. Then you can discuss strategies and/or ask for support. The other person will likely ask questions, to think about how you’d like to respond. Ultimately, deciding whether or not to talk with coworkers or a supervisor about having ADHD is a personal decision. Guidance from a mental health professional or coach can be helpful in weighing the considerations and preparing for a conversation.

Managers | Managers can help by creating an environment of psychological safety, where employees feel comfortable talking about their ADHD diagnosis and how they can best be supported. These conversations should not be forced on employees, but instead made clear that they are welcome without putting anyone on the spot. Furthermore, studies have shown that individuals with ADHD may find workplace accommodations to be helpful including reduction of auditory distractions, and managers who provide organization advice, clear delegation of tasks and clearly defined roles, or extra reminders about due dates. It’s important to remember that not all individuals want these accommodations, however. The most important thing is not to make assumptions and instead to talk to the individual in order to understand their particular needs.

Companies | In order to retain talent, minimize losses to productivity and create an environment where employees feel engaged and have the opportunity to thrive, there is a deep need for additional resources and training. Employers can provide educational materials about ADHD for all of their employees and can provide manager-specific trainings on topics such as “How to Create and Environment of Psychological Safety,” “How to Become Aware of (and Address) Our Own Biases” and “How to Provide Resources and Support for Employees with ADHD.” They can recognize the strengths of employees with ADHD diagnoses and support these employees in reaching their potential for the benefit of these employees and the company. Employers should also check benefits to make sure they are not arbitrarily excluding coverage for adults with ADHD, and consider additional benefits and resources in order to enable employees to work at their best.

With increased awareness of the gaps in supporting employees with ADHD in the workplace comes the urgent need to address these gaps through education, training and resources so as to unlock the potential of a neurodiverse workforce.

To learn more about a new kind of treatment option available for adults with ADHD:

# [Supporters Gallery — Akili Interactive](https://www.akiliinteractive.com/supporters-gallery)
Baillie Gifford is one of the UK's leading independently owned investment management firms. It is owned and run by 44 of its senior executives who operate as a partnership, a structure which has endured for over a century and which provides stability for clients and motivation for employees. It enables the firm to manage the business for the future as well as the present, with the emphasis on genuine long–term thinking rather than short-term targets.

CLSA is Asia’s leading capital markets and investment group, providing global investors with insights, liquidity and capital to drive their investment strategies. Award-winning research, an extensive Asia footprint, direct links to China, and highly experienced finance professionals differentiate our innovative products and services in alternative investment, asset management, corporate finance, capital markets, and securities and wealth management. Founded in 1986 and headquartered in Hong Kong, CLSA has 1,800 employees globally and operates in 20 cities across Asia, Australia, the Americas and Europe. CLSA is uniquely positioned to facilitate cross-border capital flows and connections between China and the world as a wholly-owned subsidiary of and the international platform of CITIC Securities (SSE: 600030, SEHK: 6030), China’s largest investment bank.

Digital Garage is a Tokyo-based internet company listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The company operates as a business context company through three segments: information technology, marketing technology, and financial technology. Through its global network and coverage, Digital Garage supports promising startup companies all around the world through funding, mentoring, networking, and business management support. The company is a previous investor in Twitter and was responsible for launching and localizing Twitter Japan.

Evidity Health Capital is a late-stage VC and growth equity firm, focused in the U.S. MedTech sector. Evidity invests in medical devices, diagnostics, and digital health leaders in the space. Evidity has been an investor in Akili since its Series A and has participated in all following fundraising rounds.

Ladera Venture Partners (LVP) is a Silicon Valley-based investment firm focused on investments at the convergence of technology and health. LVP is stage-agnostic and highly nimble, focusing on opportunities where the firm's experience, networks and insight can provide meaningful incremental value. Core focus areas include virtual care, mental health, fitness/wellness, and the application of data/AI to the health-related challenges of today and tomorrow.

Mirae Asset is a leading global diversified financial services firm operating out of 30 offices across the Americas, Asia, Europe and the Pacific. Founded in 1997, the company manages over $500bn in investor capital across its asset management, investment banking, life insurance and venture capital businesses. Since its founding, the firm has focused on investing in innovative and breakthrough ideas and teams across all sectors.

NLVP was formed in 2005 when the healthcare team spun out of the Sprout Group. The NLVP team has been built over the last two decades and managed healthcare technology portfolios in four Sprout funds and six New Leaf funds. We partner with companies across all phases, from startup to public offerings, as we look to invest in visionary teams, businesses at the forefront of innovation, and disruptive healthcare technologies across the entire healthcare system. And we share our broad perspectives, decades of experience and deep domain expertise to help our portfolio navigate the complexity of the healthcare industry. For more information, visit www.nlvpartners.com.

Polaris Partners has a 20-plus-year history of partnering with repeat entrepreneurs and world-class

innovators who are improving the way we live and work. The multibillion-dollar firm

manages specialty and diversified funds in healthcare and technology with investments across

all stages. Polaris has offices in Boston, San Francisco, and New York. Learn more at polarispartners.com.

Established in 2009, QUAD Investment Management is one of the leading asset management firms in Korea. It believes in the power of expertise, experience, and diversity. Expertise in a given field, coupled by the advantage of experience and diversity in thinking, fuels creativity which leads to innovation. One of the areas it focuses on is healthcare with dedicated investment professionals covering the entire lifecycle from private to public.

# Akili Interactive Labs, founded 2011-01-01 [(Crunchbase, 2025)](https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/akili)
Akili Interactive Labs their broad pipeline of programs to treat cognitive deficiency and improve symptoms associated with medical conditions across neurology and psychiatry, including attention-deficit hyperactivity and disorder (ADHD), major depressive disorder (MDD), autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and various inflammatory diseases.

- [Website](http://www.akiliinteractive.com)
- [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/company/akili-interactive-labs-inc-/)

customer_experience_result.output_text:
# Positive Feedback

- "Helot me 9 year old daughter to focus" [(Dhbgukfk, Apple App Store, 2024-12-24)](https://apple/12102143396)
- "My daughter LOVES THE GAME SO MUCH!!" [(Persongood, Apple App Store, 2023-03-22)](https://apple/9741692705)
- "Great game for any ADHD kid that loves video games. Most kids need to take break from Minecraft, etc and this game requires more focus and motor skills than these other games." [(Danielle Magness, Google Play Store, 2024-03-21)](https://google_play/64def928-d9b3-4644-b217-3067b64819a0)
- "Thanks for making such an important product- fun and therapeutic!" [(SugarSync Fan, Apple App Store, 2020-08-19)](https://apple/6337848577)
- "This game has helped me so much it is literally the best sometimes it can make me mad but it is so nice and helps" [(BlessingMystery, Apple App Store, 2023-06-05)](https://apple/10002729106)
- "I really like it and can feel it helping me to focus more after only two days!" [(😀😀😀😀Lukey my boiiiiii!, Apple App Store, 2023-11-05)](https://apple/10554186669)
- "I’m the kid the one that uses it and I think it’s a game changer for me😀 sometimes it gets a little boring, but it’s kind of like repetitive but it’s my favorite thing to do when I’m bored and my mom won’t let me play games/video games" [(𝕏𝕤𝕜𝕦𝕝𝕝𝕘𝕣𝕒𝕟𝕥🍓, Apple App Store, 2024-06-12)](https://apple/11375114914)
- "My kid was prescribed with ADHD and I was scared they would have to be on medication their whole life till I found this game for my kid I was so happy my kid started a bit ago and now he/she is well behaved in class end doesn’t get in trouble anymore" [(superbeddy27, Apple App Store, 2023-12-11)](https://apple/10683482368)

# Negative Feedback

- "The game is repetitive. there is no plot or story line it’s just get this done and it’ll be over with." [(ttygfyge, Apple App Store, 2023-05-31)](https://apple/9985741948)
- "This game is absolute trash, it is way too hard you can barely get any of the creatures and all the creatures your skin your face is just so freaking annoying" [(!?mn, Apple App Store, 2022-10-21)](https://apple/9207973387)
- "My ten year old hates this game, says it’s boring. All the levels are the same." [(Syberian125, Apple App Store, 2023-07-07)](https://apple/10114193627)
- "This made the ADHD WORSE for my kids!!!" [(Tiffany Thomas, Google Play Store, 2023-10-12)](https://google_play/01ddf910-6917-44b0-9813-70cd457e3944)
- "The graphics are worse than Minecraft as a child playing this game do not get if you are over 5 the concept is subway surfers but worse" [(a valid person, Apple App Store, 2020-07-30)](https://apple/6260138881)
- "There are many things that make this game problematic. First, the game is VERY critical to children and has made my daughter cry because she feels like she’s not good enough" [(Ally Selvig, Apple App Store, 2022-04-14)](https://apple/8567372071)
- "This app isn't even able to run on my Samsung galaxy. I've also seen reviews saying that this does not help with adhd at all!" [(A.M. Mangold, Google Play Store, 2023-07-27)](https://google_play/25134faf-6694-471c-a3be-38834debf857)

# Technical Issues

- "Connectivity Issue error every time I tried to use the app. I never could finish getting it setup because of this issue." [(Rebecca Bourland, Google Play Store, 2021-10-08)](https://google_play/6e7fce0b-8102-4d99-a3a6-b56e0faa6204)
- "I purchased the app through Phil Pharmacy, then purchased a new Lenovo tablet, but it wasn't compatible." [(Audrey Smith, Google Play Store, 2022-03-20)](https://google_play/c1a3defc-957c-45c5-87ff-e31913779c5d)
- "Honestly I think that the game should have a few more items that the child can change such as sensitivity and audio settings for the reason the game is having the child do hairpin turns and is having to flip the device therefore preventing them from seeing the items in which they need to tap" [(hfdhdhgv Funchal Leonardo's, Apple App Store, 2022-02-17)](https://apple/8366771880)

# Pricing and Accessibility Concerns

- "It’s bad enough to ask people to register to play a game." [(Red4man, Apple App Store, 2020-07-04)](https://apple/6157807922)
- "The game claims it requires a Dr. approved prescription, but then allows you to purchase the game for $10/month. I’ve never seen a prescription that you can just buy legally. DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY ON THIS GAME." [(Kamyleon, Apple App Store, 2023-10-12)](https://apple/10466860219)
- "I borrowed $300money to buy this game for my son and he hates this game I am a single mom and now I am so disappointed that he doesn’t want to play the game I tried everything to encourage him but it didn’t work. I really want my money back" [(artambebe, Apple App Store, 2021-07-27)](https://apple/7626270520)

The game is repetitive. there is no plot or story line it’s just get this done and it’ll be over with. you do the same thing over and over again. A lot of people are saying this. it gets really frustrating and annoying to keep steering for the boosts or obstacles. instead of engaging the audience it just angers it. it’s nothing new other than the new worlds. it’s boring. I know I only used this for 2 weeks but personally, it’s just not working. there needs to be something new! and the game is unfair. the animals move way too fast and a child’s reaction time isn’t that well developed. I know the game gets harder but *it’s not fair*. when you’re doing the same thing over and over again, it’s not fun anymore. and for this case, it NEEDS to be fun in order to “cure” ADHD. this game is not well thought out. us kids are impatient. it’s in our nature.

# Would recommend, but also wouldn’t., 3 stars [(Ally Selvig, Apple App Store, 2022-04-14)](https://apple/8567372071)
there are many things that make this game problematic.

 First, the game is VERY critical to children and has made my daughter cry because she feels like she’s not good enough, which adds on to the main point of it being very difficult to play in many ways. This includes the game making your child do sharp turns back and forth, the game doesn’t have enough sensitivity to tilting your device unless you put it completely on its side which makes you turn too fast, the game runs you through tests to see if it should be harder, and if you pass the game gets too hard which makes the game to frustrating to play, if you don’t capture the “mystic creature” you feel like your not good enough, people have reported their child destroying devices because it’s frustrating, your child has to play for 5 days a week which would be every school day unless they do it on the weekend (which we will never happen) so it adds on to homework and it ware’s your child out, if you don’t have time to do it on school days your child has to do it on the weekend, if you can’t do it for at least 3 days of the week you don’t get in what is the minimum amount of time, and many other things.

There are some upsides too. On top of all of those bad things, if your child does play the minimum amount of minuets for 5 days a week and they continue to keep that up for most of the time you do start to see a change. My child doesn’t always get 5 days a week playing for 30 mins, but as long as she does about 4-3 days a week playing for the minimum amount of minuets once in a while I don’t see it affecting the positive affect if the game at all. The game has helped my daughter be able to hear me while she is hyper-focused on something she’s doing, she has been able to control her impulse better, she has been able to come back to what she’s supposed to be doing better, she doesn’t miss multi step directions as often, she’s been able to continue trying at a difficult task instead of giving up somewhat easier, and she is able to multi task better. 

So basically, I do recommend this game because even if your child hates it and they still manage to get the minimum time in (or they occasionally get close to the minimum time in) the positive affects of the game will definitely show up in your child and they will also help your child. But I also don’t recommend it because of the many flaws that can stop your chiId from committing to playing and stop the positive affects from occurring. Really, getting the game and having your child manage to do it  is all personal to your schedule and your childs behavioral adaptations plus how their ADHD affects them. Getting the game is completely up to you but make sure you do some thinking about your child, schedule, and consider researching more about both good and bad opinions on this game before you buy it.

# Amazing! Game Changer!!!!!, 5 stars [(Bubba Wilber Williams, Apple App Store, 2021-06-24)](https://apple/7503010246)
I am a family nurse practitioner who has had ADHD since I was age 5. I’ve taken a variety of medications and seen numerous things that are purported to help with ADHD. Here are some key takeaways
1. This is a video game specifically focused on helping children age 8 to 12 with ADHD it requires supervision from a healthcare professional that’s why it’s FDA approved and needs a prescription. 

2. There is a commitment to use this 3 to 5 times a week for at least three months to see results. It does not replace medication it is adjunct therapy to be used in consideration with other treatment modalities. Basically that means the family and the healthcare professionals decide on other things that can help with ADHD this is never a standalone product.

3. As a dualy licensed family nurse practitioner and psychiatric mental health nurse practitioner I find any tools that can help support family and improve the disease process is much better than just medication alone. Enclosing research different treatments read and understand with the product does and does not do before making some flippant and derogatory comments that makes you look uneducated and uninformed.

This product may not be for everyone but for those with adhd age 8 to 12 it is a new therapeutic  tool that is a game changer

# Would recommend, but also wouldn’t., 3 stars [(Ally Selvig, Apple App Store, 2022-04-14)](https://apple/8567372071)
there are many things that make this game problematic.

 First, the game is VERY critical to children and has made my daughter cry because she feels like she’s not good enough, which adds on to the main point of it being very difficult to play in many ways. This includes the game making your child do sharp turns back and forth, the game doesn’t have enough sensitivity to tilting your device unless you put it completely on its side which makes you turn too fast, the game runs you through tests to see if it should be harder, and if you pass the game gets too hard which makes the game to frustrating to play, if you don’t capture the “mystic creature” you feel like your not good enough, people have reported their child destroying devices because it’s frustrating, your child has to play for 5 days a week which would be every school day unless they do it on the weekend (which we will never happen) so it adds on to homework and it ware’s your child out, if you don’t have time to do it on school days your child has to do it on the weekend, if you can’t do it for at least 3 days of the week you don’t get in what is the minimum amount of time, and many other things.

There are some upsides too. On top of all of those bad things, if your child does play the minimum amount of minuets for 5 days a week and they continue to keep that up for most of the time you do start to see a change. My child doesn’t always get 5 days a week playing for 30 mins, but as long as she does about 4-3 days a week playing for the minimum amount of minuets once in a while I don’t see it affecting the positive affect if the game at all. The game has helped my daughter be able to hear me while she is hyper-focused on something she’s doing, she has been able to control her impulse better, she has been able to come back to what she’s supposed to be doing better, she doesn’t miss multi step directions as often, she’s been able to continue trying at a difficult task instead of giving up somewhat easier, and she is able to multi task better. 

So basically, I do recommend this game because even if your child hates it and they still manage to get the minimum time in (or they occasionally get close to the minimum time in) the positive affects of the game will definitely show up in your child and they will also help your child. But I also don’t recommend it because of the many flaws that can stop your chiId from committing to playing and stop the positive affects from occurring. Really, getting the game and having your child manage to do it  is all personal to your schedule and your childs behavioral adaptations plus how their ADHD affects them. Getting the game is completely up to you but make sure you do some thinking about your child, schedule, and consider researching more about both good and bad opinions on this game before you buy it.

# Amazing! Game Changer!!!!!, 5 stars [(Bubba Wilber Williams, Apple App Store, 2021-06-24)](https://apple/7503010246)
I am a family nurse practitioner who has had ADHD since I was age 5. I’ve taken a variety of medications and seen numerous things that are purported to help with ADHD. Here are some key takeaways
1. This is a video game specifically focused on helping children age 8 to 12 with ADHD it requires supervision from a healthcare professional that’s why it’s FDA approved and needs a prescription. 

2. There is a commitment to use this 3 to 5 times a week for at least three months to see results. It does not replace medication it is adjunct therapy to be used in consideration with other treatment modalities. Basically that means the family and the healthcare professionals decide on other things that can help with ADHD this is never a standalone product.

3. As a dualy licensed family nurse practitioner and psychiatric mental health nurse practitioner I find any tools that can help support family and improve the disease process is much better than just medication alone. Enclosing research different treatments read and understand with the product does and does not do before making some flippant and derogatory comments that makes you look uneducated and uninformed.

This product may not be for everyone but for those with adhd age 8 to 12 it is a new therapeutic  tool that is a game changer

apple_reviews.title: The game needs a change.
apple_reviews.content:
(I’m one of the patients for this app writing this review.)
The game is repetitive. there is no plot or story line it’s just get this done and it’ll be over with. you do the same thing over and over again. A lot of people are saying this. it gets really frustrating and annoying to keep steering for the boosts or obstacles. instead of engaging the audience it just angers it. it’s nothing new other than the new worlds. it’s boring. I know I only used this for 2 weeks but personally, it’s just not working. there needs to be something new! and the game is unfair. the animals move way too fast and a child’s reaction time isn’t that well developed. I know the game gets harder but *it’s not fair*. when you’re doing the same thing over and over again, it’s not fun anymore. and for this case, it NEEDS to be fun in order to “cure” ADHD. this game is not well thought out. us kids are impatient. it’s in our nature.

apple_reviews.title: Would recommend, but also wouldn’t.
apple_reviews.content:
there are many things that make this game problematic.

 First, the game is VERY critical to children and has made my daughter cry because she feels like she’s not good enough, which adds on to the main point of it being very difficult to play in many ways. This includes the game making your child do sharp turns back and forth, the game doesn’t have enough sensitivity to tilting your device unless you put it completely on its side which makes you turn too fast, the game runs you through tests to see if it should be harder, and if you pass the game gets too hard which makes the game to frustrating to play, if you don’t capture the “mystic creature” you feel like your not good enough, people have reported their child destroying devices because it’s frustrating, your child has to play for 5 days a week which would be every school day unless they do it on the weekend (which we will never happen) so it adds on to homework and it ware’s your child out, if you don’t have time to do it on school days your child has to do it on the weekend, if you can’t do it for at least 3 days of the week you don’t get in what is the minimum amount of time, and many other things.

There are some upsides too. On top of all of those bad things, if your child does play the minimum amount of minuets for 5 days a week and they continue to keep that up for most of the time you do start to see a change. My child doesn’t always get 5 days a week playing for 30 mins, but as long as she does about 4-3 days a week playing for the minimum amount of minuets once in a while I don’t see it affecting the positive affect if the game at all. The game has helped my daughter be able to hear me while she is hyper-focused on something she’s doing, she has been able to control her impulse better, she has been able to come back to what she’s supposed to be doing better, she doesn’t miss multi step directions as often, she’s been able to continue trying at a difficult task instead of giving up somewhat easier, and she is able to multi task better. 

So basically, I do recommend this game because even if your child hates it and they still manage to get the minimum time in (or they occasionally get close to the minimum time in) the positive affects of the game will definitely show up in your child and they will also help your child. But I also don’t recommend it because of the many flaws that can stop your chiId from committing to playing and stop the positive affects from occurring. Really, getting the game and having your child manage to do it  is all personal to your schedule and your childs behavioral adaptations plus how their ADHD affects them. Getting the game is completely up to you but make sure you do some thinking about your child, schedule, and consider researching more about both good and bad opinions on this game before you buy it.

apple_reviews.title: Amazing! Game Changer!!!!!
apple_reviews.content:
I am a family nurse practitioner who has had ADHD since I was age 5. I’ve taken a variety of medications and seen numerous things that are purported to help with ADHD. Here are some key takeaways
1. This is a video game specifically focused on helping children age 8 to 12 with ADHD it requires supervision from a healthcare professional that’s why it’s FDA approved and needs a prescription. 

2. There is a commitment to use this 3 to 5 times a week for at least three months to see results. It does not replace medication it is adjunct therapy to be used in consideration with other treatment modalities. Basically that means the family and the healthcare professionals decide on other things that can help with ADHD this is never a standalone product.

3. As a dualy licensed family nurse practitioner and psychiatric mental health nurse practitioner I find any tools that can help support family and improve the disease process is much better than just medication alone. Enclosing research different treatments read and understand with the product does and does not do before making some flippant and derogatory comments that makes you look uneducated and uninformed.

This product may not be for everyone but for those with adhd age 8 to 12 it is a new therapeutic  tool that is a game changer

apple_reviews.title: Based on flawed logic about ADHD
apple_reviews.content: Adult with inattentive ADHD and a degree in Psychology. Played the demo. Graphics are nice, but the concept is based on flawed logic about ADHD. It's easy to pay attention to games for hours because they're so stimulating. It's difficult to pay attention to schoolwork for even a few minutes because it's not very engaging. Being good at the former in no way translates to being good at the latter.

reviews.cons: Akili is a start-up with a single launched app, that has gone public in a down market without yet having substantial revenue. This creates a general sense of pressure and stress, especially in the east coast office where more sales and business is managed. Pay tends to be below standard (even before the market downturn).
reviews.pros: Company mission stands to innovate healthcare with digital games. Really great people, very competent, dedicated to delivering on the promise. West coast office has a wonderful culture and office. Company culture promotes a healthy work-life balance, without crunch.

reviews.cons: There is a lot of ambiguity that might not be the best for some employees that thrive more in strictly structured biotechs. We work across a multitude of industries and are the first in ours. I wish I had more time with people sometimes, but we are all super busy and it can be tough getting time on calendars.
reviews.pros: Passion for helping others is at the forefront of everything Akili does and it is obvious from the moment of your first interview. Every single employee I have met has a passion for our mission, including the leadership team. We are transparent about everything, we work super well cross functionally and really strive to continue pushing the envelope and growing as individuals, as teams and as a company. We are small but mighty and in my department we focus on broadening our diversity (neurodivergence, race, sex, gender, ethnicity, religion, disabilities, you name it!) and bringing the best talent to our patients and caregivers.

reviews.cons: Fast-paced, but you are made well aware
reviews.pros: Culture, Benefits -- including unlimited PTO.

reviews.cons: As a small agile company, communication can occasionally occur a bit late and cause work to require pivoting in other directions. Though this is likely common at many companies.
reviews.pros: Good culture. Everyone really cares about the caregivers and patients that they build products for

reviews.advice: Care about your people instead of shareholders. Hard to believe the patient is being put first
reviews.cons: Their word means absolutely nothing.
reviews.pros: I would not recommend working here

reviews.advice: Keep it up
reviews.cons: None - I love it here
reviews.pros: Flexibility, great and cutting edge work

reviews.advice: Let's keep our company DNA intact as we scale.
reviews.cons:
We're going to grow fast, so keeping our culture intact while maintaining our scalability is going to be tough. There are also some inherent obstacles to having two different industries represented on opposite coasts, but we're doing our best. We are maximizing face time, improving our on-boarding, and trying to bridge that gap with extensive communication. 
I guess if you're allergic to dogs that could be a Con.
reviews.pros:
You know how sometimes you're at a company so awesome that you're waiting for the catch? It's been over 2 years and I'm still waiting to see what the catch is. I don't say that lightly. Everyone here, regardless of background (and there are some fascinating backgrounds here), is 100% behind our company goal to improve people's lives. 
Everyone is passionate, talented, and excited to be here. In the west coast office, our culture is on point (weekly bbq's, a dedicated Fun Club for planning team opportunities, kayaks, etc) and it helps us stay focused. We value work/life balance and provide flexibility to do so.
This is honestly such a rare kind of company where our mission statements, personalities, drive, and experience all align for a greater good. We are all personally invested and work hard to pioneer a product that sounds like something out of Star Trek: The Next Generation
reviews.summary: Waiting to find out what the catch is.

reviews.advice: Keep your commitment to being as transparent as possible, keep communicating with employees through the various channels, model what you want for the rest of the team and keep going.
reviews.cons: Given we are "pioneers" in the field of digital medicine and we have some glass to break (pardon the pun) the dedication and commitment is ever present and like most start ups- it keeps us on our toes
reviews.pros: Akili has a mission that all employees are enthusiastic in support of fulfilling.  Helping kids with ADHD with something other than a pill is something most people (in or out of Akili) can stand by behind and fight hard for.
reviews.summary: Best Culture both in Good Times and in Challenging Times

reviews.advice:
Continue to find new ways to create transparency, when possible.  

Keep working on a hiring strategy that builds Akili for its future endeavors, focusing on integrating the gaming and healthcare sides of the business.  One of the biggest challenges we face is facilitating strong communication between the industry backgrounds represented here.  Employees are excited to know what other groups are doing.  Encouraging that will yield positive results and help employees to better understand the full picture.

Keep focusing on career growth, education and building up employees.  This creates a stronger desire to work harder and fosters loyalty.  This creates contagious positive energy.

Trust that the people you've hired are able to accomplish what you brought them in to do.  Delegate to capable, driven people.  This is the only way to grow effectively, while utilizing the talent you've invested in.  

Find new ways to connect the employees to the patients, to remind them of who they're doing all of this for and the impact that it's having on individuals' lives.
reviews.cons:
Definitely more challenging to attract top talent in Marin, due to transportation and commute, for some.  It is a strong lifestyle work/life balance and a beautiful area to work.  It's a trade-off.

Government interdependencies and regulatory oversight is always a challenge and we are no exception.  

There are inherent challenges in creating an overarching company culture that is consistent, due to multiple industries being represented, across two coasts.  This is a possible area for improvement, with lots of potential.
reviews.pros:
The first thing that drew me to the Akili was the mission….the products that Akili is developing will change the face of therapeutically active digital medicine.  It’s fascinating work to be a small part of.  One of the reasons I plan on staying for a while is the people who work here.  It would be difficult to find a more collaborative, positive, inclusive group of people, who genuinely love the work they do.  They support each other, regardless of the benefit to themselves or their specific skillset.  It’s also fun.  

The company goes out of it's way to offer above average benefits, compensation and employee appreciation with a creative bent. It is evident that a lot of work has gone into this.  How many times in your career can you say you’ve looked forward to coming into work every day?  For me, that is a motivating factor.  Companies talk about their “culture.”  This company works at building an environment that is setting us up for success.  This is a reflection on the carefully chosen leadership and the teams that they've built.  While all different in background and personality, this is a group of individuals that compliment one another in their intellectual abilities and personality traits.  Even the most dynamic people in this company are humble, no matter their level.  Leadership here is largely inclusive and goes above and beyond to offer support, to build up employees, helping them along on their career path.  I believe this is why the company is able to retain its people.    

Akili is a continuous learning environment.  There's opportunity to learn every single day that we’re here.  There is no getting bored or feeling stagnated here.  There is opportunity to grow in your career and we are supported in continued education, networking, and clear set goals.  We have recently implemented a program to give substantive feedback more frequently. If you excel at Akili, there is career growth opportunity and stability.
reviews.summary: Game Changers, Empathetic Innovators & Badasses Apply Here....

reviews.cons: Akili is a start-up, that means things are always changing!  This isn't always a bad thing, but you have to be prepared to go with the flow, try keep up, and put yourself out there to get things done outside your job description sometimes.
reviews.pros: The team at Akili is wonderful to work with, not only because they are intelligent & upbeat people, but because they are dedicated to the mission of helping the patients we serve.   Akili also embraces the flexible work schedule & offers benefits that reflect the company's values - like charity matching!
reviews.summary: Fast moving company with amazing people!

reviews.cons: Poor management, unclear vision, shifting priorities
reviews.pros: Extremely smart, kind, and hardworking coworkers

reviews.advice: Keep communicating and keep valuing your employees ... it shows.
reviews.cons: Some people thrive in fast paced, constantly changing environments where they have the opportunity to wear many hats and stretch themselves and have an impact every day!  Not a con... just not for everyone.
reviews.pros: Great Mission! Lots of growth happening at Akili! Creative, inclusive and fun environment.  Leadership walks it’s talk with transparency.  Akili is doing groundbreaking work, crossing industries and the work is challenging and exciting.

reviews.cons: I don't know if I can say anything is a true con. There challenges in being in a high growth company, but they are not cons.
reviews.pros: Every place I have worked in the past touts their commitment to culture. Akili is the first place where their actions have backed up their words.

glassdoor_result.summary_markdown:
# Employee Sentiments

## Reasons Employees Like Working at Akili Interactive

### Mission and Impact
- "Great Mission! Lots of growth happening at Akili! Creative, inclusive and fun environment." [(Director Level New Employee, Glassdoor, 2018-05-11)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW20544359.htm)
- "Helping kids with ADHD with something other than a pill is something most people (in or out of Akili) can stand by behind and fight hard for." [(Vice President, Glassdoor, 2020-04-29)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW32943791.htm)

### Culture and Environment
- "The team at Akili is wonderful to work with... dedicated to the mission of helping the patients we serve." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2018-11-07)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW23311176.htm)
- "The company culture is legendary. BBQ's, health and wellness days, unlimited PTO, special outings." [(Senior Technical Artist, Glassdoor, 2020-04-30)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW32964804.htm)

### Employee Support and Growth
- "It’s also fun... The company goes out of its way to offer above average benefits, compensation and employee appreciation." [(Manager, Glassdoor, 2019-04-15)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW25693111.htm)
- "There is opportunity to grow in your career and we are supported in continued education, networking, and clear set goals." [(Manager, Glassdoor, 2019-04-15)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW25693111.htm)

## Reasons Employees Dislike Working at Akili Interactive

### Management and Communication Issues
- "Culture is changing fast, and people are starting to lose their faith in the management team's sincerity." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2019-05-16)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW26171474.htm)
- "Keeping your company decision makers but letting go of the people who do their bidding...what?!" [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2023-01-18)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW72735533.htm)

### Job Security and Stability
- "Goes public and then a massive layoff 4 months later? Great concept, poor execution - on a lifeline." [(Manager, Glassdoor, 2023-01-12)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW72564121.htm)
- "New Regime Means Frequent Layoffs." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2023-09-14)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW80072026.htm)

## Key Events or Changes in the Company

### Growth and Layoffs
- "There were recent layoffs mostly around the lower end of the org chart and promotions within the executive management at the same time." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2019-05-16)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW26171474.htm)
- "Lay off 35% of org but keep your C-Suite..." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2023-01-18)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW72735533.htm)

### Company Acquisition
- "Not sure any more since acquisition by Virtual Therapeutics." [(Vice President, Glassdoor, 2024-11-17)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW92927456.htm)

## Specific Details About Benefits

### Employee Benefits
- "Competitive healthcare benefits + perks such as unlimited PTO." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2019-10-06)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW29650652.htm)
- "Flexibility, great and cutting edge work." [(Legal, Glassdoor, 2022-07-23)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW67063079.htm)

### Work-Life Balance
- "Company provides good work/life balance and most people are amazing to work with." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2019-05-16)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW26171474.htm)
- "The culture at Akili is inclusive, simply fun, and works hard to acknowledge everyone's individual contributions." [(Executive Assistant, Glassdoor, 2021-05-28)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-Akili-Interactive-Labs-RVW47594695.htm)
